block.p: Progress Is Seen in Talks As Phone Strike Continues Negotiators for more than 86,000 striking telephone workers and Verizon Communications reached tentative agreement on several critical issues, but an overall settlement to the 13-day walkout remained bogged down in the details.

Verizon agreed to move less than 1 percent of its employees each year to other places, and it broadened an agreement to organize employees of Verizon's wireless division, people close to the talks said. [Page C2.]

Chip Stocks Extend Their Rally Semiconductor stocks extended their recent rally. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index rose 2.1 percent, bringing its six-day gain to 20 percent. It is still down 10 percent since mid-July. Still, losses elsewhere sent the Nasdaq composite index down 10.53 points, or 0.3 percent, to 3,930.34. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 4.35 points, to 1,491.72. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 9.16 points, to 11,046.48. [C4.]

Delay Sought in Nasdaq Plan Review Two members of Congress who oversee the Securities and Exchange Commission, Senator Phil Gramm and Representative Thomas Bliley, have asked the commission to delay its review of a plan that is intended to give investors more information about the way Nasdaq stocks are traded and fairer prices. [C2.]

Harcourt Plans an Online College Harcourt General will formally apply on Monday for approval to operate an online college. The educational publisher is trying to join a handful of private companies offering college-level courses over the Internet. [C2.]

Health Care Companies Heartened Heartened by a federal court victory in Philadelphia last week in the managed care wars, lawyers for several large health insurance companies are seeking to consolidate a slew of lawsuits accusing managed care companies of misleading their customers. [C3.]

U.S. Trade Deficit Climbs to Record The United States trade deficit widened to a record $30.6 billion in June as the appetite for foreign crude oil increased even as prices were the highest in nearly 10 years. The deficit expanded from a revised $30.3 billion in May, the Commerce Department reported. [C5.]

Union Puts Firestone on Notice The United Steelworkers of America said it had issued a strike notice to Firestone, posing another potential burden for the tire maker, which is already conducting a huge tire recall. The union said contract extension agreements, covering more than 8,000 workers at nine plants, would expire in 14 days. [C2.]

Bidding War Seen for Seagram Unit Diageo of Britain, the world's leading liquor company, and Pernod Ricard of France said they would team up to compete for the wine and spirits business of Seagram. The move is likely to start a bidding war with Allied Domecq, the No. 2 liquor concern, that could push the price toward $9 billion. [C3.]

Insurers Agree to $1.2 Billion Deal The American International Group, one of the world's largest insurers, agreed to acquire the HSB Group, parent of the Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection and Insurance Company, for about $1.2 billion in stock. The deal will bolster A.I.G.'s range of products by adding several specialty insurance lines. [C4.]

QXL to Buy Rival for $256.5 Million The British Internet auctioneer QXL agreed to buy a German rival, Ricardo.de, although it lowered its original offer by nearly three-quarters, to 171 million pounds, or $256.5 million, after learning Ricardo's fourth-quarter revenue had declined sharply. [C3.]
